where ∝proportional-to\propto stands for “proportional to”. Typically, we have XF​b​F​T​L<XcF​T​L≪XfF​T​L<XF​Lsuperscript𝑋𝐹𝑏𝐹𝑇𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑋𝐹𝑇𝐿𝑐much-less-thansubscriptsuperscript𝑋𝐹𝑇𝐿𝑓superscript𝑋𝐹𝐿X^{FbFTL}<X^{FTL}_{c}\ll X^{FTL}_{f}<X^{FL}.

III-D Experimental Results

In this section, we consider the application of FL, FTL and FbFTL to the VGG-16 CNN model [41] and transfer the knowledge learned from ImageNet dataset [42] to CIFAR-10 dataset [43].

ImageNet is a vast online database containing over 14 million images, each with hand-annotated labels describing the classification types or intended outputs for training. The pre-trained source model we use for TL was created on the 2012 ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge (ILSVRC2012, [71]), and the images come from 1000 different categories. As an illustration, we provide 10 samples with their labels in Fig. 3.

CIFAR-10 is a database of 600006000060000 images, each with one of N=10𝑁10N=10 distinct labels. Out of these images, 500005000050000 images are used for training and 100001000010000 images for testing. Fig. 4 showcases the first ten samples with their labels. Note that these samples have simple labels and appear more blurred compared to those in ImageNet due to their lower resolution/dimension.

In Fig. 5, we depict the structure of VGG-16 used for training on CIFAR-10. For TL, we consider the first half of the layers marked blue as the feature extraction sub-model f𝜽11subscriptsuperscript𝑓1superscript𝜽1f^{1}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{1}} and directly transfer this sub-model from that trained on ImageNet. We deem the latter part marked yellow as the task-specific sub-model f𝜽22subscriptsuperscript𝑓2superscript𝜽2f^{2}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{2}} and randomly initiate this part. For FbFTL, the dimension of the intermediate output is Nmc−=4096subscriptsuperscript𝑁subscript𝑚𝑐4096N^{-}_{m_{c}}=4096.

To train the model on CIFAR-10, we utilize Nvidia GeForce GPU with CUDA to run the algorithms with PyTorch [72]. We assume that there are U=6250𝑈6250U=6250 clients in total, each iteration takes a fraction C=1.28×10−3𝐶1.28superscript103C=1.28\times 10^{-3} of all clients, and each batch contains Ku=8subscript𝐾𝑢8K_{u}=8 samples. In the two most commonly used deep learning tools TensorFlow (including Keras) [73] and PyTorch, the default data type of each number has 32 bits and therefore d=32𝑑32d=32 bits. The learning rate is 10−2superscript10210^{-2}, the momentum of the optimizer is 0.90.90.9, and the L2 penalty is 5×10−45superscript1045\times 10^{-4}.

In Table III, we compare the performances of FL, SFL, FTL updating the full model (FTLf), FTL updating the task-specific sub-model (FTLc), and FbFTL. For increased fairness in the comparison of payloads, we further demonstrate the performances FLlow and FTLl​o​wfsuperscriptsubscriptabsent𝑓𝑙𝑜𝑤{}_{f}^{low}, which are the FL and FTLf algorithms that terminate training process when the validation accuracy reaches those of FTLc and FbFTL (i.e., ≈86%absentpercent86\approx 86\%). As we have analyzed, the other algorithms require I​U​C𝐼𝑈𝐶IUC successfully uploaded batches, while FbFTL only requires ∑u=1UKusuperscriptsubscript𝑢1𝑈subscript𝐾𝑢\sum_{u=1}^{U}{K_{u}} batches. Also, FL, SFL, FTLf and FTLc require uploading d​∑m=1MTm𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑇𝑚d\sum_{m=1}^{M}{T_{m}} bits, d​(Ku​Nmc−+∑m=mcMTm)𝑑subscript𝐾𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝑁subscript𝑚𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑚subscript𝑚𝑐𝑀subscript𝑇𝑚d(K_{u}N^{-}_{m_{c}}+\sum_{m=m_{c}}^{M}{T_{m}}) bits, d​∑m=1MTm𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑇𝑚d\sum_{m=1}^{M}{T_{m}} bits, and d​∑m=mcMTm𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑚subscript𝑚𝑐𝑀subscript𝑇𝑚d\sum_{m=m_{c}}^{M}{T_{m}} bits, respectively, for each batch, while FbFTL only requires uploading d​Nmc−𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑁subscript𝑚𝑐dN^{-}_{m_{c}} bits for each batch. In the third row of the table, we observe that the FbFTL algorithm significantly reduces the uplink payload per batch by four orders of magnitude (i.e. a factor of 10−4superscript10410^{-4}) compared to the other algorithms for each client. Additionally, in the fourth row, FbFTL leads to a reduction of five orders of magnitude (i.e. a factor of 10−5superscript10510^{-5}) in the total uplink payload during training when compared to the other algorithms. These results demonstrate that FbFTL is apparently the most efficient scheme. FbFTL also results in a substantial decrease in the overall downlink payload. If larger models are trained for more complex tasks or if the size of the training dataset is more limited, the difference in payload could be even greater. In (14) through (17), we have described the overall computation time complexity required for training at clients as O​(X)𝑂𝑋O(X). In the second-to-last row of the table, we quantify and provide this time complexity for each method by counting the number of multiplications among floating numbers. We readily observe that FbFTL requires the least computation time and power consumption at the clients, and has two orders of magnitude reduction compared to FL, SFL and FTLf, since it only runs the forward pass over feature extraction sub-model for each sample one time. We further note that for FbFTL, the computation complexity at the PS is also low with X=3.00×1014𝑋3.00superscript1014X=3.00\times 10^{14}. Furthermore, we note that different number of clients C​U𝐶𝑈CU in each iteration does not affect the performance of FbFTL, but a large number of clients C​U𝐶𝑈CU reduces the performance of FL and FTL, since it defines the minimum “training batch size” C​U​Ku𝐶𝑈subscript𝐾𝑢CUK_{u}. The performance of FL and FTL will decrease with an overwhelmingly large training batch size, which is another benefit of FbFTL. We in the experiment pick a small C​U=8𝐶𝑈8CU=8 so that the benchmark schemes (i.e., FL, FTLf, and FTLc) have the best performance (at which point FTLc and FbFTL have the same performance). Moreover, we also observe that FTLc and FbFTL only update a small portion of the parameters and exhibit a slight decrease in validation accuracy, which is the trade-off for the reduced payload. However, we will show in Section IV and Section V that under communication efficiency or privacy constraints, FbFTL may also prevail in terms of validation accuracy in certain situations.

Furthermore, we note that in transfer learning, there is an additional trade-off between privacy protection, performance and payload. When partitioning a model into feature extraction sub-model and task-specific sub-model, choosing the cut layer closer to the output better preserves data privacy, while picking a cut layer closer to the input improves the training performance. In order to demonstrate such a trade-off, we next consider a language model as our application scenario. In FL, FTL, and FbFTL on natural language processing tasks, we consider tasks where the model and the intermediate features are not proprietary or private, and thus we assume that the clients are willing to share them while keeping the local data private As an example, we show the results on a conversation summary task SAMSum [74] with 32128 distinct token types out of 14732 training dialogues and 819 testing dialogues. For instance, dialogue ID 13728867 in SAMSum is “Olivia: Who are you voting for in this election? Oliver: Liberals as always. Olivia: Me too!! Oliver: Great”, and ground truth summary is “Olivia and Olivier are voting for liberals in this election.” For this task, we deploy a language model FLAN-T5-small [75], which is a transformer with 110 million parameters, including 8 encoders and 8 decoders. This model is pre-trained and the dataset is relatively small, so we do not have FL in this case. We assume that there are U=7366𝑈7366U=7366 clients, each has Ku=2subscript𝐾𝑢2K_{u}=2 dialogues, and each iteration takes a fraction C=5.43×10−4𝐶5.43superscript104C=5.43\times 10^{-4} of all clients. Our experiment is based on HuggingFace [76] with learning rate 2×10−42superscript1042\times 10^{-4}.

In Table IV, we compare the performances of FTL and FbFTL in terms of ROUGE-1 score, which measures the match between the generated text and reference text. A larger ROUGE-1 indicates better performance. We note that FTLf trains all components including encoders, decoders, embedding and the final linear layer. On the other hand, FTLc and FbFTL freeze embedding, and may or may not freeze several encoders close to the input prompts. The number of trained encoders is given in the second row of Table IV. For instance, the performance results in the third and fourth columns are for FTLc and FbFTL that have trained all encoders (and hence have not frozen any of them), while the other columns provide the performances with 4 or 2 encoders trained (indicating that 4 or 6 encoders close to the input are frozen). We do not need to freeze decoders since label privacy leakage converges to zero with shuffled batches, as will be shown in Section V. In Table IV, we observe that FbFTL reduces the uplink and downlink payload by similar orders of magnitude as in the VGG-16 experiment. Furthermore, we notice that training less layers or encoders leads to a slight reduction in ROUGE-1 score but it does not guarantee lower payload. While FTL may require more iterations to arrive convergence, FbFTL may need to broadcast a larger feature extraction sub-model.

IV Robustness Analysis

In this section, we compare the performance of FbFTL with that of FL and FTL under the same packet loss rate (PLR) for each batch being uploaded, and illustrate the robustness of FbFTL against packet losses, data insufficiency, and compression, including quantization, sparsification and error feedback.

IV-A Packet Loss

As we have demonstrated in the previous section, gradient-based FedAvg FL frameworks including FL and FTL upload the gradient update gu=∑k=1Ku∇𝜽L​(f𝜽|su,k)subscriptg𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑢subscript∇𝜽𝐿conditionalsubscript𝑓𝜽subscripts𝑢𝑘\textbf{g}_{u}=\sum_{k=1}^{K_{u}}{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{L(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}|\textbf{s}_{u,k})}} iteratively, where each batch contains the gradient summation from all samples of the client. In contrast, our proposed FbFTL uploads the data for each sample only once, and each batch contains extracted features zu,ksubscriptz𝑢𝑘\textbf{z}_{u,k} and output yu,ksubscripty𝑢𝑘\textbf{y}_{u,k} from one sample.

In (7), we have shown that each batch for gradient-based FL is much larger than each batch for FbFTL (by about 104superscript10410^{4} larger in our experiments), and we assume that the packets to transmit both types of batches consist of multiple transmission blocks of the same size. For both types of packets, we consider measuring the robustness of all frameworks against packet loss caused by block losses due to network congestion or link outage (e.g., as a result of deep fading in wireless networks). For each learning framework whose packet consists of nbsubscript𝑛𝑏n_{b} transmission blocks, we consider the same block loss rate (BLR). The PLR without retransmission is

PLR=1−(1−BLR)nb.PLR1superscript1BLRsubscript𝑛𝑏\text{PLR}=1-(1-\text{BLR})^{n_{b}}. (18)

Obviously, PLR highly depends on the value of nbsubscript𝑛𝑏n_{b}. FbFTL has significantly lower packet size and consequently we expect much lower PLR for the given same BLR. We show the significant performance difference among different learning frameworks in our experiments at the end of this section.

If, on the other hand, we allow at most nrsubscript𝑛𝑟n_{r} retransmissions for all packets and assume the channel state of each transmission to be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), we can lower the PLR and achieve similar packet-level reliability. However, this is realized at the cost of higher total uplink payload. Specifically for each learning framework requiring uplink payload P𝑃P, the expected uplink payload with retransmissions is

P​(BLR)=∑n′=1nbPnb​∑n=0nr(BLR)n=P​∑n=0nr(BLR)n.𝑃BLRsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑛′1subscript𝑛𝑏𝑃subscript𝑛𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑛𝑟superscriptBLR𝑛𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑛𝑟superscriptBLR𝑛P(\text{BLR})=\sum_{n^{\prime}=1}^{n_{b}}\frac{P}{n_{b}}\sum_{n=0}^{n_{r}}(\text{BLR})^{n}=P\sum_{n=0}^{n_{r}}(\text{BLR})^{n}. (19)

We note that ∑n=1nr(BLR)nsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛𝑟superscriptBLR𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{n_{r}}(\text{BLR})^{n} is the expected number of retransmissions, which is the same for all different learning frameworks. If the transmission has a fixed bandwidth, ∑n=1nr(BLR)nsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛𝑟superscriptBLR𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{n_{r}}(\text{BLR})^{n} also represents the delay factor of the total transmission. We further note that if BLR=0BLR0\text{BLR}=0, then P​(BLR)=P𝑃BLR𝑃P(\text{BLR})=P. Otherwise, P​(BLR)=P+P​∑n=1nr(BLR)n>P𝑃BLR𝑃𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛𝑟superscriptBLR𝑛𝑃P(\text{BLR})=P+P\sum_{n=1}^{n_{r}}(\text{BLR})^{n}>P. Notice that the increase in the payload P​∑n=1nr(BLR)n𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛𝑟superscriptBLR𝑛P\sum_{n=1}^{n_{r}}(\text{BLR})^{n} grows with P𝑃P and nrsubscript𝑛𝑟n_{r}. Hence, learning frameworks with higher payload experience a higher increase in payload when retransmissions are introduced.

IV-B Data Insufficiency

At the end of Section III-A, we have discussed the benefit that FbFTL does not require additional online uploads from the clients to test different sets of hyper-parameters, while gradient-based frameworks need to run the entire uploading process multiple times. In practice, in addition to hyper-parameters, another intangible aspect prior to training is whether there exists a sufficient number of participating clients and training samples. If the planned set of samples is insufficient to train the neural network, gradient-based frameworks require rerunning the overall process with more clients, which leads to high consumption and potential waste of both computational and transmission resources. However, FbFTL only requires the new clients to compute and upload their batches, and hence there is no waste of transmission resources.

IV-C Quantization, Sparsification and Error Feedback

To further reduce the uplink payload of gradient-based frameworks, there have been extensive works on gradient compression, including gradient sparsification [77, 78] and gradient quantization [63, 64], especially signSGD, the extreme case in which each element is reduced to be binary valued without scaling [79]. Several recent studies utilize error feedback (or quantization and sparsification with memory) that reduces the error in compression at client’s local device to improve the updates in future iterations [50, 49].

For gradient-based frameworks utilizing gradient update gusubscriptg𝑢\textbf{g}_{u} with Xgsubscript𝑋𝑔X_{g} elements, we denote the sparsification function as 𝒮r​(⋅):ℝXg→ℝXg:subscript𝒮𝑟⋅→superscriptℝsubscript𝑋𝑔superscriptℝsubscript𝑋𝑔\mathcal{S}_{r}(\cdot):\mathbb{R}^{X_{g}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{X_{g}}, where r∈(0,1]𝑟01r\in(0,1]. This function keeps the value of r​Xg𝑟subscript𝑋𝑔rX_{g} elements in the vector with the highest absolute values, and set the value of all other elements to 0. We denote the quantization function as 𝒬q​(⋅):ℝXg→ℝXg:subscript𝒬𝑞⋅→superscriptℝsubscript𝑋𝑔superscriptℝsubscript𝑋𝑔\mathcal{Q}_{q}(\cdot):\mathbb{R}^{X_{g}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{X_{g}} where q∈ℤ+𝑞superscriptℤq\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}, and this function quantizes each element in the vector to q𝑞q bits within the max/min range. Furthermore, we denote the error memory vector for client u𝑢u at iteration t𝑡t as mu,t∼ℝXgsimilar-tosubscriptm𝑢𝑡superscriptℝsubscript𝑋𝑔\textbf{m}_{u,t}\sim\mathbb{R}^{X_{g}}. Therefore, the process of quantization and sparsification with error feedback at iteration t𝑡t is described as follows:

gu′=𝒬q​(𝒮r​(gu+mu,t)),subscriptsuperscriptg′𝑢subscript𝒬𝑞subscript𝒮𝑟subscriptg𝑢subscriptm𝑢𝑡\textbf{g}^{\prime}_{u}=\mathcal{Q}_{q}(\mathcal{S}_{r}(\textbf{g}_{u}+\textbf{m}_{u,t})), (20)
mu,t+1=gu+mu,t−gu′,subscriptm𝑢𝑡1subscriptg𝑢subscriptm𝑢𝑡subscriptsuperscriptg′𝑢\textbf{m}_{u,t+1}=\textbf{g}_{u}+\textbf{m}_{u,t}-\textbf{g}^{\prime}_{u}, (21)

where gu′subscriptsuperscriptg′𝑢\textbf{g}^{\prime}_{u} is uploaded to the PS, and the local error memory vector is updated to mu,t+1subscriptm𝑢𝑡1\textbf{m}_{u,t+1}. For initialization, mu,1=0subscriptm𝑢10\textbf{m}_{u,1}=\textbf{0}.

Similarly, for FbFTL utilizing extracted feature zu,ksubscriptz𝑢𝑘\textbf{z}_{u,k} with Xzsubscript𝑋𝑧X_{z} elements, we may also apply sparsification and quantization. However, error feedback is not applicable, because there is only one upload iteration in FbFTL, and the extracted feature is not additive unlike the gradient. Therefore, the process of quantization and sparsification for FbFTL is described as follows:

zu,k′=𝒬q​(𝒮r​(zu,k)),subscriptsuperscriptz′𝑢𝑘subscript𝒬𝑞subscript𝒮𝑟subscriptz𝑢𝑘\textbf{z}^{\prime}_{u,k}=\mathcal{Q}_{q}(\mathcal{S}_{r}(\textbf{z}_{u,k})), (22)

where zu,k′subscriptsuperscriptz′𝑢𝑘\textbf{z}^{\prime}_{u,k} is uploaded to the PS.

In both cases, the compression rate is close to 2d/q/rsuperscript2𝑑𝑞𝑟2^{d/q}/r where d𝑑d is the number of bits for the representation of the original data type. We note that there is also a potential drawback in the practical deployment of sparsification and error feedback. On the one hand, while all other operations including training, communication, inference, quantization and error feedback have time complexity no more than O​(X′)𝑂superscript𝑋′O(X^{\prime}) where X′superscript𝑋′X^{\prime} is the total number of parameters in the neural network, we notice that depending on the sparsification ratio r𝑟r, sparsification requires up to O​(Xg​log⁡Xg)𝑂subscript𝑋𝑔subscript𝑋𝑔O(X_{g}\log{X_{g}}) time complexity for gradient-based frameworks and O​(Xz​log⁡Xz)𝑂subscript𝑋𝑧subscript𝑋𝑧O(X_{z}\log{X_{z}}) time complexity for FbFTL. Typically, we have O​(Xz)≪O​(Xg)=O​(X′)much-less-than𝑂subscript𝑋𝑧𝑂subscript𝑋𝑔𝑂superscript𝑋′O(X_{z})\ll O(X_{g})=O(X^{\prime}), and FbFTL can achieve more significant time complexity reduction in local sparsification computation compared to gradient-based frameworks. On the other hand, by compensating for the compression error in future iterations, the error feedback significantly improves the training performance when the compression rate is high, i.e., r𝑟r and q𝑞q are low. However, the error feedback requires O​(Xg)𝑂superscript𝑋𝑔O(X^{g}) additional memory throughout the entire training process and not just during the local training. Also, we demonstrate below in the experimental results that the gradient-based frameworks do not prevail even with error feedback.

IV-D Experimental Results

In this section, we numerically demonstrate the aforementioned robustness metrics in our experiments with the VGG-16 CNN model on transfer learning from ImageNet dataset to CIFAR-10 dataset.

In Fig. 7, we show the PLR (without retransmissions) of different learning frameworks when the block size equals the batch size of FbFTL (i.e., the BLR equals the PLR of FbFTL). As we have shown in the row of uplink payload per batch of Table III, the batch sizes of other learning frameworks are about 104superscript10410^{4} times larger than that of FbFTL. Due to the huge difference in the batch sizes, the PLR curves of the other learning frameworks almost reach 111 when the PLR of FbFTL is less than 0.0010.0010.001 (or equivalently when BLR<0.001absent0.001<0.001). The difference is still substantially high if a few rounds of retransmissions are allowed in gradient-based frameworks. Fig. 7 provides the magnified plot of Fig. 7 for BLR<0.001absent0.001<0.001, and we note that the curve of FL and the curve of FTL that updates full model overlap since they have the same number of parameters to update and therefore have the same batch size. In this figure, we again observe that the PLR curves of learning mechanisms other than FbFTL quickly approach 111 within the considered range of BLR <0.001absent0.001<0.001, while the PLR of FbFTL (being equal to BLR) stays below 0.0010.0010.001.

Since FbFTL has significantly lower PLR, we subsequently analyze its performance with different amount of data. In Fig. 8, we see that FbFTL has relatively high validation accuracy even with only 10% of the samples. Indeed, when we have only 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the samples (i.e., the case with 50 samples), the accuracy is 82.5%percent82.582.5\% even with PLR=0.5absent0.5=0.5. Furthermore, we observe that as PLR increases, the accuracy curves remain relatively flat, and experience sharp drops only when PLR approaches 1. Therefore, FbFTL is considerably robust against data insufficiency and PLR. We note that such robustness requires significantly more training iterations I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} such that I​U𝐼𝑈IU and I′​U′superscript𝐼′superscript𝑈′I^{\prime}U^{\prime} have the same order of magnitude, where I𝐼I is the original number of training iterations with all U𝑈U participating clients, and I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} is the number of training iterations with limited data from U′superscript𝑈′U^{\prime} clients. In the case of smaller number of participating clients U′≪Umuch-less-thansuperscript𝑈′𝑈U^{\prime}\ll U and PLR =0absent0=0, FbFTL requires the same level of computational power consumption and more total downlink payload compared to the original case with U𝑈U clients. However, there is a huge reduction in total uplink payload and total local computational power consumption, because FbFTL only requires uploading once for each participating client. In comparison, gradient-based frameworks require uploading in every training iteration, and therefore there is no such benefit in terms of reduced uplink payload and local computations, while they also suffer from higher downlink payload. Similarly, we have the performance curves for FLAN-T5-small in Fig. 9.

In Table V, we show the validation accuracy of each framework with data from all U𝑈U clients and PLR =0absent0=0, but for different values of quantization size q𝑞q bits and sparsification ratio r𝑟r. In the experiment, we pick the same set of values for q𝑞q and r𝑟r as in [77, 78]. Note that the highest reduction in uplink payload is achieved when we set r=0.001𝑟0.001r=0.001 and q=2𝑞2q=2. However, even in this case, the uplink payload of gradient-based frameworks (i.e., FTL, FTLf, FTLc) is still greater than that of FbFTL with r=1𝑟1r=1 and q=32𝑞32q=32. Moreover, with such drastic reduction, gradient-based schemes achieve lower accuracies compared to that of FbFTL with r=1𝑟1r=1 and q=32𝑞32q=32. Therefore, even without sparsification and more restrictive quantization (e.g., q=8𝑞8q=8 or q=2𝑞2q=2), FbFTL outperforms gradient-based frameworks in terms of both accuracy and payload reduction. We can further reduce the uplink payload of FbFTL by choosing r<1𝑟1r<1 and q<32𝑞32q<32. We note that FbFTL in the extreme case of r=0.001𝑟0.001r=0.001 only keeps 4 elements in the extracted features to distinguish among 10 classes. In this setting, the information is severely limited and is insufficient to make an accurate prediction, resulting in accuracy levels of 65%percent6565\% for FbFTL. If, on the other hand, we pick a certain threshold on the validation accuracy, for instance 82%, FbFTL requires the sparsification ratio to be no lower than r=0.01𝑟0.01r=0.01 (which is 101010 times more than that of the best gradient-based framework), but still maintains a reduction of more than four orders of magnitude (i.e., reduction of 10−4superscript10410^{-4}) in total uplink payload compared to the gradient-based algorithms while achieving the same validation accuracy. Such good performance of FbFTL without error feedback is due to the robustness of extracted features against noise. If we consider the error from compression as random noise, the extracted features from a well-trained source model is typically robust to noise while gradient update does not necessarily have the same level of robustness.

V Privacy Analysis

In previous sections, we have described the FbFTL framework where each client u𝑢u with Kusubscript𝐾𝑢K_{u} samples uploads extracted features zu,ksubscriptz𝑢𝑘\textbf{z}_{u,k} and output yu,ksubscripty𝑢𝑘\textbf{y}_{u,k} for k=1,…,Ku𝑘1…subscript𝐾𝑢k=1,\ldots,K_{u} instead of the gradient update gu=∑k=1Ku∇𝜽L​(f𝜽|su,k)subscriptg𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑢subscript∇𝜽𝐿conditionalsubscript𝑓𝜽subscripts𝑢𝑘\textbf{g}_{u}=\sum_{k=1}^{K_{u}}{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{L(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}|\textbf{s}_{u,k})}} as done in FL and FTL with FedAvg. In this section, we conduct a privacy analysis by studying privacy leakage to a potential adversary, and propose protection strategies. In particular, we consider leakage due to the unveiling of information regarding the outputs/labels {yu,k}subscripty𝑢𝑘\{\textbf{y}_{u,k}\} (henceforth referred to as label privacy leakage) and the unveiling of intermediate features {zu,k}subscriptz𝑢𝑘\{\textbf{z}_{u,k}\} (henceforth referred to as feature privacy leakage). For example, during the training process of a classifier to distinguish the character in a photo to be a dog or a cat, the identity of the character being labeled as a dog is considered as label privacy, while the feature privacy includes additional information of the certain photo besides its label privacy such as the color of the fur and the furniture in the background.

The label privacy leakage quantifies how much information about the batch of a targeted client is revealed to an adversary through the information on the outputs {yu,k}subscripty𝑢𝑘\{\textbf{y}_{u,k}\} (or type of label in classification problems). The information on the outputs/labels can be of statistical nature or can be obtained via the unveiling of the outputs to the adversary. The former considers the information leakage via the knowledge of the general sample output distribution, while the latter specifies the leakage when the adversary has access to the output/label values. We analyze the label privacy leakage via the entropy and mutual information from the adversary’s perspective and propose an uploading design that randomly shuffles all batches to conceal the dependency between the client address and the output data.

Feature privacy leakage describes the amount of information that possibly leaks when the adversary obtains uploaded contents from clients. We will analyze the feature privacy leakage via the differential privacy (DP) framework [7] and provide comparisons between FbFTL and the gradient-based frameworks (FL and FTL, in which cases feature privacy is leaked when the adversary obtains the gradient updates) through experiments and numerical results.

V-A Label Privacy Leakage

First, we analyze the label privacy leakage. While FbFTL directly uploads the output in each batch for each sample, we note that FL and FTL with FedAvg that update the final layer also leak the output, and hence label privacy leakage also occurs in these cases. According to [80], the count of each output type in a batch can be numerically solved given the average gradient. Adversaries with certain prior knowledge on the training data are able to gain further knowledge and reconstruct the input from the average gradient, such as deep leakage [81] or gradient inversion [82, 83]. Although the following label privacy analysis applies to both feature-based FbFTL and gradient-based FedAvg frameworks, we in label privacy analysis use the word “batch” to indicate all uploaded information from one client with multiple samples. Compared to the high-dimensional gradient gusubscriptg𝑢\textbf{g}_{u} or feature zu,ksubscriptz𝑢𝑘\textbf{z}_{u,k}, the output y also potentially reveals clients’ private information but up to a certain degree. In this setting, we analyze the conditions under which the label privacy leakage (with statistical information) vanishes. We also address the role of shuffling the output information from all clients as a way of hiding the client’s address from uploaded content when adversary has access to outputs.

To validate these approaches, we analyze the private output information leakage of a specific batch to a potential adversary without client addresses. According to [84], the privacy loss of a query can be evaluated as the difference in the privacy before and after the query. In our setting, we determine the amount of label privacy via the uncertainty from the adversary’s perspective, and quantify it by utilizing the entropy formulation.

As shown in Fig. 10, we consider a common learning task in which the output y∈[0,1]Nysuperscript01𝑁\textbf{y}\in[0,1]^{N} is an axis-aligned unit vector with one element having a value of 1 indicating the label associated with the given input, and all others equal to 0. We assume that each sample {xu,k,zu,k,yu,k}subscriptx𝑢𝑘subscriptz𝑢𝑘subscripty𝑢𝑘\{\textbf{x}_{u,k},\textbf{z}_{u,k},\textbf{y}_{u,k}\} is independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.). Each client u∈𝒰𝑢𝒰u\in\mathcal{U} transmits one batch with Ku=Ksubscript𝐾𝑢𝐾K_{u}=K samples, including the outputs/labels {yu,k}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscripty𝑢𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\textbf{y}_{u,k}\}_{k=1}^{K}. Therefore for this client, there are NKsuperscript𝑁𝐾N^{K} different possible ordered batches of outputs in total (where N𝑁N is the number of possible different labels that can be associated with the input).

Assuming that the order in the batch does not contain information, we use ℬℬ\mathcal{B} to denote the set of possible batches without order from client u𝑢u, and the privacy information of the real batch b𝑏b from client u𝑢u is the sum vector ∑k=1Kyu,k=[n1,by,n2,by,…,nN,by]subscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑘1subscripty𝑢𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑦1𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑦2𝑏…subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑦𝑁𝑏\sum^{K}_{k=1}\textbf{y}_{u,k}=[n^{y}_{1,b},n^{y}_{2,b},\ldots,n^{y}_{N,b}], where ∑a=1Nna,by=Ksubscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑎1subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑦𝑎𝑏𝐾\sum^{N}_{a=1}n^{y}_{a,b}=K. Subsequently, the number of possible batches without order is the combination with the replacement of N𝑁N items taken K𝐾K times and is given by

|ℬ|=(N+K−1K).ℬbinomial𝑁𝐾1𝐾|\mathcal{B}|=\binom{N+K-1}{K}. (23)

We denote the index of client u𝑢u’s batch as a random variable B𝐵B, and the index of the uploaded batch as B=b∈ℬ𝐵𝑏ℬB=b\in\mathcal{B}. We denote the type of the label yu,ksubscripty𝑢𝑘\textbf{y}_{u,k}’s distribution as Pysubscript𝑃𝑦P_{y}. Typically to achieve better performance, in most of the machine learning applications we desire a uniform distribution over different labels, and we denote the uniform distribution over N𝑁N labels as Py,uni=[1N,1N,…,1N]subscript𝑃𝑦uni1𝑁1𝑁…1𝑁P_{y,\text{uni}}=[\frac{1}{N},\frac{1}{N},\ldots,\frac{1}{N}].

To evaluate the adversary’s knowledge on one given batch B=b𝐵𝑏B=b of a target victim client, we consider the presumed distribution PBsubscriptP𝐵\textbf{P}_{B} of the batch B𝐵B from the adversary’s perspective to quantify the adversary’s uncertainty through the entropy H​(B)𝐻𝐵H(B) of the given batch.

V-A1 Label Privacy Leakage with Statistical Information

A weak adversary without any prior knowledge of the sample distribution may presume the sample distribution to be uniform, i.e., Py,unisubscript𝑃𝑦uniP_{y,\text{uni}}. In this case, the distribution of ordered batches from the adversary’s perspective is also uniform with probability 1/NK1superscript𝑁𝐾1/N^{K}. Each batch index b∈ℬ𝑏ℬb\in\mathcal{B} without order corresponds to K!/∏a=1Nna,by!𝐾subscriptsuperscriptproduct𝑁𝑎1subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑦𝑎𝑏K!/{\prod^{N}_{a=1}n^{y}_{a,b}!} different batch indices with order, and hence the adversary’s presumed probability distribution of batches without order (under the assumption of uniform sample distribution) is PB|uni=[p0,1,p0,2,…,p0,|ℬ|]subscriptPconditional𝐵unisubscript𝑝01subscript𝑝02…subscript𝑝0ℬ\textbf{P}_{B|\text{uni}}=[p_{0,1},p_{0,2},\ldots,p_{0,|\mathcal{B}|}], where

p0,b=K!NK​∏a=1Nna,by!.subscript𝑝0𝑏𝐾superscript𝑁𝐾subscriptsuperscriptproduct𝑁𝑎1subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑦𝑎𝑏p_{0,b}=\frac{K!}{N^{K}\prod^{N}_{a=1}n^{y}_{a,b}!}. (24)

Therefore from the weak adversary’s perspective, the uncertainty of the batch from client u𝑢u with known format and size but without prior knowledge about the content can be quantified by the entropy

H​(B|Py,uni)=−∑b=1|ℬ|p0,b​log2⁡p0,b𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦unisubscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑏1subscript𝑝0𝑏subscript2subscript𝑝0𝑏H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})=-\sum^{|\mathcal{B}|}_{b=1}p_{0,b}\log_{2}{p_{0,b}} (25)

where the condition in the entropy signifies that this is the entropy under the assumption of uniformly distributed samples.

On the contrary, a stronger adversary with the ability to steal and decode a large amount of uploaded data may learn the structure of the DNN and is able to decode the labels of the K𝐾K samples in a batch, and hence such an adversary is likely to have the prior knowledge of the general distribution of batches from a large number of clients. In the case that the true sample distribution Py,truesubscript𝑃𝑦trueP_{y,\text{true}} is known, we denote the strong adversary’s presumed distribution of the batch from client u𝑢u as

PB|true=[p1,p2,…,p|ℬ|],subscriptPconditional𝐵truesubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2…subscript𝑝ℬ\textbf{P}_{B|\text{true}}=[p_{1},p_{2},\ldots,p_{|\mathcal{B}|}], (26)

and the corresponding uncertainty at the adversary in the original setting before query is

H​(B|Py,true)=−∑b=1|ℬ|pb​log2⁡pb.𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦truesubscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑏1subscript𝑝𝑏subscript2subscript𝑝𝑏H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{true}})=-\sum^{|\mathcal{B}|}_{b=1}p_{b}\log_{2}{p_{b}}. (27)

By comparing the uncertainty between the weak adversary and the strong adversary, we give the definition of label privacy leakage with statistical information.

Definition 1.

Label Privacy Leakage with Statistical Information: For an adversary without prior knowledge of the sample distribution (and hence that initially assumes uniform sample distribution), the label privacy leakage is the amount of information regarding the target batch B𝐵B that leaks to the adversary when it obtains the true distribution Py,truesubscript𝑃𝑦trueP_{y,\text{true}}. This privacy leakage can be formulated as follows:

Lsl=H​(B|Py,uni)−H​(B|Py,true).subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑠𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦uni𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦trueL^{l}_{s}=H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})-H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{true}}). (28)

Note that H​(B|Py,uni)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦uniH(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}}) is the uncertainty in B𝐵B under the assumption that the labels are uniformly distributed. H​(B|Py,true)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦trueH(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{true}}) is the remaining uncertainty in B𝐵B when the true sample distribution is learned by the adversary. Hence, the difference is the information gained by or equivalently leaked to the adversary.

Machine learning tasks typically require dataset balancing. If the data collection process is sufficiently well designed so that each output type is almost equally likely and we have PB|true→PB|uni→subscriptPconditional𝐵truesubscriptPconditional𝐵uni\textbf{P}_{B|\text{true}}\to\textbf{P}_{B|\text{uni}}, then the label privacy leakage Lsl→0→subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑠0L^{l}_{s}\to 0. As we have illustrated in section III-A, achieving this goal is more viable in FbFTL.

V-A2 Label Privacy Leakage with Access via Query

Next, we analyze the label privacy leakage when the adversary has access to the shuffled outputs (e.g., via a query). In the worst case, the strongest query is the process that the adversary acquires all batches without clients’ addresses. Specifically, we assume that the adversary has access to randomly shuffled U𝑈U batches. Recall that there are |ℬ|ℬ|\mathcal{B}| different types of batches. We use c​(b)𝑐𝑏c(b) to denote the count for type b𝑏b batches among given U𝑈U batches. With this definition, we have ∑b=1|ℬ|c​(b)=Usuperscriptsubscript𝑏1ℬ𝑐𝑏𝑈\sum_{b=1}^{|\mathcal{B}|}c(b)=U. For different set of U𝑈U batches, the counts will be different. We define 𝒞Usubscript𝒞𝑈\mathcal{C}_{U} as a random vector of counts of different types of batches among a total of U𝑈U batches. Hence, for given U𝑈U batches, the realization of this vector is 𝒞𝒰=cU=[c​(1),c​(2),…,c​(|ℬ|)]subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈𝑐1𝑐2…𝑐ℬ\mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}=[c(1),c(2),\ldots,c(|\mathcal{B}|)]. In the absence of any other statistical information, the adversary can utilize the following empirical distribution of B𝐵B based on the frequency of each batch type among all U𝑈U batches:

PB,emp≜P​{B|𝒞𝒰=cU}=[c​(1)U,c​(2)U,…,c​(|ℬ|)U].≜subscriptP𝐵empPconditional-set𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈𝑐1𝑈𝑐2𝑈…𝑐ℬ𝑈\textbf{P}_{B,\text{emp}}\triangleq\textbf{P}\{B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}\}=\bigg{[}\frac{c(1)}{U},\frac{c(2)}{U},\ldots,\frac{c(|\mathcal{B}|)}{U}\bigg{]}. (29)

With this empirical distribution based on the shuffled U𝑈U batches, the adversary’s uncertainty is given by the entropy

H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU)=−∑b=1|ℬ|c​(b)U​log2⁡c​(b)U.𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑏1𝑐𝑏𝑈subscript2𝑐𝑏𝑈H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U})=-\sum^{|\mathcal{B}|}_{b=1}\frac{c(b)}{U}\log_{2}{\frac{c(b)}{U}}. (30)

In the case in which the adversary has acquired U𝑈U batches via the query and knows the distribution Py,truesubscript𝑃𝑦trueP_{y,\text{true}} of the samples, we denote the adversary’s presumed distribution as P​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU,Py,true)Pconditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈subscript𝑃𝑦true\textbf{P}(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U},P_{y,\text{true}}), and its uncertainty on client u𝑢u’s batch as H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU,Py,true)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈subscript𝑃𝑦trueH(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U},P_{y,\text{true}}).

First, we establish the following result.

Lemma 1.

Assume that the true sample distribution is known. Once U𝑈U batches are revealed to the adversary, the distribution of the batches (from the adversary’s perspective) depends only on the frequency/count of each batch type in the unveiled U𝑈U batches and not on the sample distribution, i.e.,

P(B=b|𝒞𝒰=cU,Py,true)=P{B=b|𝒞𝒰=cU}.\displaystyle P(B=b\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U},P_{y,\text{true}})=P\{B=b\,|\,\mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}\}. (31)
Proof.

We prove this lemma by utilizing the Bayes’ rule and determining the ratio of two conditional probabilities as follows:

P(B=b|𝒞𝒰=cU,Py,true)=P​(𝒞𝒰=cU,B=b|Py,true)P​(𝒞𝒰=cU|Py,true)=(U−1)!(c​(b)−1)!​∏b′≠bc​(b′)!U!c​(b)!​∏b′≠bc​(b′)!=(U−1)!(c​(b)−1)!U!c​(b)!=c​(b)U=P​{B=b|𝒞𝒰=cU}.\begin{aligned} P(B=b\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U},P_{y,\text{true}})=&\frac{P(\mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U},B=b|P_{y,\text{true}})}{P(\mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}|P_{y,\text{true}})}\\ =&\frac{\frac{(U-1)!}{(c(b)-1)!\prod_{b^{\prime}\neq b}c(b^{\prime})!}}{\frac{U!}{c(b)!\prod_{b^{\prime}\neq b}c(b^{\prime})!}}\\ =&\frac{\frac{(U-1)!}{(c(b)-1)!}}{\frac{U!}{c(b)!}}\\ =&\frac{c(b)}{U}\\ =&P\{B=b\,|\,\mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}\}.\end{aligned} (32)

∎

This result indicates that the batch distribution is equal to the empirical distribution in (29). Consequently, we also have the following characterization for the entropies:

H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU,Py,true)=H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈subscript𝑃𝑦true𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈\displaystyle H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U},P_{y,\text{true}})=H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}) (33)

Next, we give the definition of the label privacy leakage with query, and identify a condition under which the privacy leakage vanishes.

Definition 2.

Label Privacy Leakage with Query: For an adversary with prior knowledge of the true sample distribution Py,truesubscript𝑃𝑦trueP_{y,\text{true}}, the label privacy leakage with query is the amount of information regarding the batch of a target client that leaks to the adversary when it obtains the randomly shuffled set of uploaded U𝑈U batches including the target’s batch. This privacy leakage can be formulated as follows:

Lql=H​(B|Py,true)−H​(B|Py,true,𝒞𝒰=cU)=H​(B|Py,true)−H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU).subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑞absent𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦true𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦truesubscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈missing-subexpressionabsent𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦true𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈\begin{aligned} L^{l}_{q}&=H(B\ |\,P_{y,\text{true}})-H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{true}},\,\mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U})\\ &=H(B\ |\,P_{y,\text{true}})-H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}).\end{aligned} (34)
Lemma 2.

As the number of shuffled batches goes to infinity, the label privacy leakage with query converges to 0, i.e.,

limU→∞Lql=0.subscript→𝑈subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑞0\lim\limits_{U\to\infty}L^{l}_{q}=0. (35)
Proof.

As U𝑈U grows without bound, we have limU→∞PB,emp=PB|truesubscript→𝑈subscriptP𝐵empsubscriptPconditional𝐵true\lim\limits_{U\to\infty}\textbf{P}_{B,\text{emp}}=\textbf{P}_{B|\text{true}} by the law of large numbers, and as a result, we have the characterization that limU→∞H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU)=H​(B|Py,true)subscript→𝑈𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦true\lim\limits_{U\to\infty}H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U})=H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{true}}). Hence, the label privacy leakage Llqsubscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑞𝑙L^{q}_{l} with query converges to 0. ∎

Note that if the adversary does not initially know even the distribution of the samples and assume a uniformly distributed samples, then total label privacy leakage after the unveiling of the U𝑈U batches to the adversary can be defined as

Ltl=Lsl+Lql=H​(B|Py,uni)−H​(B|𝒞𝒰=cU).superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑡𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑠𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑞𝑙𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦uni𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝒰subscript𝑐𝑈\displaystyle L_{t}^{l}=L_{s}^{l}+L_{q}^{l}=H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})-H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C_{U}}=c_{U}). (36)

If the shuffled dataset is perfectly balanced and we have PB,emp=PB|unisubscriptP𝐵empsubscriptPconditional𝐵uni\textbf{P}_{B,\text{emp}}=\textbf{P}_{B|\text{uni}}, the total label privacy leakage is zero, i.e., Ltl=Lsl+Lql=0superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑡𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑞0L_{t}^{l}=L^{l}_{s}+L^{l}_{q}=0.

V-B Feature Privacy Leakage

In this section, we analyze the privacy leakage on the input x via uploaded content. Such privacy leakage includes the information that is not necessarily needed to determine the output y, and we will define it as feature privacy. Different from label privacy where the adversary knows the implication of each type of output (or the meaning of each label), it is hard to define the adversary’s prior knowledge on the gradients and extracted features, and it is unlikely to cancel feature privacy leakage via shuffling. Furthermore, it is hard to quantify and analyze the entropy and mutual information of gradients and extracted features because of the complexity of neural networks. Instead, we will analyze the feature privacy leakage via differential privacy.

For FbFTL, the intermediate output z is also referred to as the smashed data in split learning [85, 86], and cannot be directly transformed back to the input x due to the nonlinearity of the activation functions in each layer. However, it is possible that FbFTL leaks privacy to some extent and partially reveals the input. Since the feature before a fully connected layer from a sample can be analytically solved from its gradient [87], it is possible that gradient-based frameworks also leak the input. The strategy to extract the input from FedAvg gradients includes deep leakage [81, 87, 88] and gradient inversion [82, 83], and is extensively studied for image recognition. However, deep leakage highly depends on the dataset and DNN structure. Therefore, an analysis of the privacy leakage beyond label privacy is needed to identify what may be partially revealed regarding the input x from the uploaded features.

Differential privacy (DP) provides an upper bound on the privacy leakage using a different measuring approach, and we compare the feature privacy preserving performances of FbFTL and other schemes via DP. In the DP analysis of feature privacy, we denote the training samples for each batch as d and the function that generates the upload vector as g𝑔g. More specifically, d=su,kdsubscripts𝑢𝑘\textbf{d}=\textbf{s}_{u,k} and g​(d)=zu,k=f𝜽11​(xu,k)𝑔dsubscriptz𝑢𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑓1superscript𝜽1subscriptx𝑢𝑘g(\textbf{d})=\textbf{z}_{u,k}=f^{1}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{1}}(\textbf{x}_{u,k}) for FbFTL, while d=⋃k=1Ksu,kdsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscripts𝑢𝑘\textbf{d}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{K}\textbf{s}_{u,k} and g​(d)=gu=∑k=1K∇𝜽L​(f𝜽|su,k)𝑔dsubscriptg𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript∇𝜽𝐿conditionalsubscript𝑓𝜽subscripts𝑢𝑘g(\textbf{d})=\textbf{g}_{u}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}{L(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}|\textbf{s}_{u,k})}} for gradient-based FedAvg frameworks. Similarly as in [89, 90, 91], we define the feature privacy through the following condition: g𝑔g satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP if for any subset of possible outputs G𝐺G it holds that

Pr​{g​(d)∈G}≤eϵ​Pr​{g​(d′)∈G}+δ,Pr𝑔d𝐺superscript𝑒italic-ϵPr𝑔superscriptd′𝐺𝛿\text{Pr}\{g(\textbf{d})\in G\}\leq e^{\epsilon}\text{Pr}\{g(\textbf{d}^{\prime})\in G\}+\delta, (37)

where d and d′superscriptd′\textbf{d}^{\prime} differ in a single sample with the true distribution Py,truesubscript𝑃𝑦trueP_{y,\text{true}}.

In [92], it has been shown via moments accountant approach that adding Gaussian noise n to g​(d)𝑔dg(\textbf{d}) prior to transmission maintains an overall privacy loss of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta). Typically, the variance of the noise depends on the maximum distance max⁡‖g​(d)−g​(d′)‖norm𝑔d𝑔superscriptd′\max{\|g(\textbf{d})-g(\textbf{d}^{\prime})\|} for any two adjacent inputs d and d′superscriptd′\textbf{d}^{\prime}. To provide a fair comparison between different learning frameworks, we consider the maximum relative distance R=maxd,d′⁡max⁡|g​(d)−g​(d′)|K​std​(g​(d))𝑅subscript𝑑superscript𝑑′𝑔d𝑔superscriptd′𝐾std𝑔dR=\max\limits_{d,d^{\prime}}{\frac{\max\left|g(\textbf{d})-g(\textbf{d}^{\prime})\right|}{K\text{std}(g(\textbf{d}))}} within training set for each framework, where |⋅||\cdot| denotes absolute value and std​(⋅)std⋅\text{std}(\cdot) denotes the standard deviation. Thus, the additive Gaussian noise to each output g​(d1)𝑔subscriptd1g(\textbf{d}_{1}) should be n∼𝒩​(0,σ2​R2​std2​(g​(d1))​I)similar-ton𝒩0superscript𝜎2superscript𝑅2superscriptstd2𝑔subscriptd1I\textbf{n}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma^{2}R^{2}\text{std}^{2}(g(\textbf{d}_{1}))\textbf{I}) to mitigate the feature privacy leakage, and the lower bound of the σ𝜎\sigma value can be determined via the moments accountant approach.

As a result, according to [92, Theorem 1], there exist constants c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} such that for any ϵ<c1​C2​Iitalic-ϵsubscript𝑐1superscript𝐶2𝐼\epsilon<c_{1}C^{2}I, the training process with g​(d)+n𝑔dng(\textbf{d})+\textbf{n} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 if we choose σ≥c2​Cϵ​−I​log⁡δ𝜎subscript𝑐2𝐶italic-ϵ𝐼𝛿\sigma\geq\frac{c_{2}C}{\epsilon}\sqrt{-I\log{\delta}}, where I𝐼I is the number of iterations (I=1𝐼1I=1 for FbFTL), and C𝐶C is the fraction of clients selected in each iteration. When the value of δ𝛿\delta and noise factor σ​R𝜎𝑅\sigma R are fixed, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for FedAvg DP decreases as the batch size K𝐾K grows, but increases as training iterations I𝐼I (and potentially, the number of retraining for hyper-parameter tuning) increase. However, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for FbFTL DP does not depend on these factors. Furthermore, the final performance also depends on the robustness of each framework against noise. Therefore, we demonstrate the comparisons via experiments in the following subsection.

V-C Experimental Results

In our experiments, we utilize the dataset CIFAR-10 which has N=10𝑁10N=10 types of labels, and is well-balanced (i.e., Py,true=Py,unisubscript𝑃𝑦truesubscript𝑃𝑦uniP_{y,\text{true}}=P_{y,\text{uni}}). We generate shuffled batches according to the uniform sample distribution Py,unisubscript𝑃𝑦uniP_{y,\text{uni}} and evaluate the total label privacy leakage in different scenarios in Fig. 11. The blue curve plots the initial uncertainty H​(B|Py,uni)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦uniH(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}}) for different values of K𝐾K (where K𝐾K is the number of samples from each client). Each of the other curves shows the uncertainty given shuffled data H​(B|𝒞U=cU)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝑈subscript𝑐𝑈H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}) with fixed total amount of samples U​K𝑈𝐾UK from all clients, and the number of clients U𝑈U is determined by each value of K𝐾K accordingly. By Definition 1 and Definition 2, the total label privacy leakage given shuffled data is Ltl=Lsl+Lqlsuperscriptsubscript𝐿𝑡𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑙𝑞L_{t}^{l}=L^{l}_{s}+L^{l}_{q} and is equal to the difference H​(B|Py,uni)−H​(B|𝒞U=cU)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦uni𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝑈subscript𝑐𝑈H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})-H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}). We see that H​(B|Py,uni)≈H​(B|𝒞U=cU)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝑃𝑦uni𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝑈subscript𝑐𝑈H(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})\approx H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}) when K𝐾K is small, and thus the label privacy is well preserved. However, for given value of the product U​K𝑈𝐾UK, H​(B|𝒞U=cU)𝐻conditional𝐵subscript𝒞𝑈subscript𝑐𝑈H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}) diminishes fast once a certain threshold of K𝐾K is exceeded. Therefore, we note that the label privacy leakage becomes high when K𝐾K is large. As addressed before, the label privacy applies in the same way to both FbFTL and gradient-based FedAvg frameworks, and hence a smaller K𝐾K might be preferred in order to preserve the label privacy. However, current FL privacy analyses typically focus on DP that provides a relatively loose upper bound on the total local privacy. Within the DP setting, studies typically consider a small number of clients and assume that each client obtains hundreds of samples, if not thousands of, to achieve improved DP performance. However, as we have observed above, a setting with higher values of K𝐾K can lead to higher label privacy loss (in addition to requiring more training epochs and achieving less validation accuracy). This leads to the important conclusion that the balance between different types of privacy leakage needs to be considered carefully.

To compare the DP performances of feature privacy leakage, we apply different noise levels σ𝜎\sigma on upload content g​(d)𝑔dg(\textbf{d}) of different frameworks to achieve the same level (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) of privacy, and compare the validation accuracy at convergence with different K𝐾K in Fig. 12. In our experiments, we implement the moments accountant via Rényi Divergence-based DP accountant to get a tighter bound. With fixed δ=10−6𝛿superscript106\delta=10^{-6}, each plot shows the validation accuracy at convergence as a function of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for given K𝐾K. We note that higher ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon indicates weaker DP protection, lower noise level σ𝜎\sigma, and thus higher accuracy (closer to the original performance without noise). As shown in Fig. 11, label privacy is better preserved at K=4𝐾4K=4, and we show the DP performance within the same setting in Fig. 12(a). While gradient-based FedAvg frameworks totally fail, FbFTL has good performance because it has much smaller data size |g​(d)|𝑔d|g(\textbf{d})| and is more robust against noise, as it receives constant data instead of varying perturbation in each training iteration and converges to a sub-optimal model. Such advantage of FbFTL remains until K𝐾K increases to 100 as shown in Fig. 12(b), where FTL that updates the task-specific sub-model outperforms FbFTL at ϵ≥4italic-ϵ4\epsilon\geq 4 as they have the same data size |g​(d)|𝑔d|g(\textbf{d})| while the noise level of FedAvg decreases as K𝐾K increases. However, the label privacy completely leaks for K≥16𝐾16K\geq 16 as we have seen in Fig. 11. FedAvg for K≥16𝐾16K\geq 16 only prevails in protecting the subset of feature privacy that is not mitigated via shuffling. In Fig. 12(c), we show the comparison for even larger K=600𝐾600K=600, where all types of FedAvg perform better than FbFTL.

Note that it is extremely difficult to analytically evaluate the volume of feature privacy leakage that can be mitigated via shuffling. Howeover, we can compare the performances of FbFTL and FedAvg for a given K𝐾K via experimental results as done above. One key conclusion we have is the following. In terms of privacy preservation, FbFTL is preferred when K𝐾K is small (i.e., each client obtains a small set of samples), and gradient-based FedAvg is preferred when K𝐾K is large.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we have presented a novel communication-efficient federated transfer learning method. In this proposed feature-based federated transfer learning (FbFTL), the features and outputs are uploaded rather than the gradient updates. We have provided a thorough description of the system design and the learning algorithm, and compared its theoretical payload with that of federated learning and federated transfer learning. Our results demonstrate substantial reductions in both uplink and downlink payload when using FbFTL. Via experiments, we have further shown the effectiveness of the proposed FbFTL by showing that FbFTL reduces the uplink payload by up to five orders of magnitude compared to that of existing methods. Subsequently, we have demonstrated that FbFTL with small batch size has significantly less packet loss rate than gradient-based frameworks, and illustrated its robustness against data insufficiency and quantization. Finally, we have considered different types of privacy leakage, and analyzed mitigation approaches. Specifically, we have first analyzed label privacy leakage with both statistical knowledge and query (resulting in access to the label outputs). We have identified a condition under which label privacy vanishes. We have also addressed feature privacy and considered a DP mechanism for preserving this privacy. We have shown that with small K𝐾K and shuffling that eliminates label privacy leakage, FbFTL also attains good differential feature privacy protection. These characterizations and results render FbFTL a communication-efficient, robust, and privacy-preserving novel federated transfer learning scheme.
